Water electrolysis (WE) is an attractive advanced technology for the production of H2. A key issue in the WE is to develop suitable catalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), where a relatively large energy loss occurs. The Ir-doped NiCo2O4 catalysts exhibit the formation of a solid solution and a porous nanostructure. The oxygen vacancies formed by Ir doping can enhance the electrocatalytic activity for the OER owing to increased electrical conductivity and tunable adsorption energies of OH- and H2O. In comparison to IrO2 as a representative OER catalyst, the Ir(10 at%) doped NiCo2O4 catalyst (10-Ir-NCO) exhibits the better OER performance (overpotential of 303 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and its stability for 20,000 s. In addition, in the overall water splitting test, the 10-Ir-NCO || Pt/C exhibits the excellent OER activity (a low overpotential of 0.5 V at 100 mA cm−2) and stability (20 h at 50 mA cm−2). Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction NiCo2O4 Ir doping Nanostructure catalyst 1 Introduction Water electrolysis (WE) is attractive as an advanced technology to produce H2 as a clean fuel for hydrogen electric vehicles and powder plants by the electrochemically dissociation of water [1]. In general, water electrolysis systems operate with alkaline or acidic charge carriers [2]. In an alkaline medium, hydrogen gas is generated at the cathode in WE by the following electrochemical reactions [3]: (1) 2 H2O + 2e- → H2 + 2OH- E0 = −0·83 V (cathode) (2) 2OH- → 1/2 O2 + H2O + 2e- E0 = 0.40 V (anode) (3) H2O → H2 + 1/2 O2 E0 = 1·23 V (total) The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occur on AWE catalysts at the cathode and anode, respectively [4,5]. Typically, the cathode reaction mechanism for the HER is as follows [2,6–8]: (4) H2O(l) + e- → H* + OH-(aq) (5) H* + H2O(l) + e- → H2(g) + OH-(aq) (6) H* + H* → H2(g) + 2* In contrast, the reaction mechanism for the OER at the anode is relatively complicated as follows ( Fig. 1) [9–12]: (7) M + OH- → MOH- + e- (8) MOH* + OH- → MO* + H2O(l) (9) MO* + OH- → MOOH* + e- (10) MOOH* + OH- → M + O2(g) + H2O(l) Since the OER requires a significantly higher overpotential than does the HER, the OER is a rate-determining step (rds) in the overall reactions [9,13]. Thus, the selection of an appropriate anode catalyst is crucial for achieving the high-performance alkaline-based WE. In general, anode catalysts for the OER need to satisfy the following requirements: excellent catalytic activity, high electrical conductivity, and stability under high potential and alkaline conditions [14]. IrO2 has been intensively studied as an anode catalyst, owing to its excellent catalytic activity and stability [3,15,16]. However, to overcome its critical disadvantages such as its high cost and limited availability, the doping of transition metals (Ni, Co, Cr, Mn, Fe) in the IrO2 structure, deposition of IrO2 on an electrically conductive material such as antimony-doped tin oxide, and Ir-doped transition metal oxides have been intensively explored [17–21]. Specifically, for Ir-based oxide catalysts, the IrO6 geometry in hollandite, perovskite, pyrochlore and rutile structures in the OER could affect the formation of the intermediate OOH* , that is, the rds of the OER [22–26]. However, the mechanism of enhancement of the OER resulting from the IrO6 geometry remains unknown. Moreover, Co-based oxide catalysts as host structures have been doped with transitional metals [4,27]. Hei et al. reported enhanced activity and stability using Fe-doped Co3O4 coated with carbon [28]. Morphologically controlled CuxCo2O4 with different amounts of Cu prepared by a hydrothermal method exhibited improved OER performance due to increased number of active surface sites [29]. In particular, NiCo2O4 (NCO) and Fe-doped NCO exhibit excellent OER activity owing to their doping effect and morphology control [30]. In addition, Zn-doped NCO exhibited improved electrochemical active surface area and electrical conductivity, promoting OER performance [31]. Bao et al. reported that the oxygen vacancy in the NCO structure might result in improved OER activity, increasing electrical conductivity and reducing the adsorption energy of H2O [14]. In this study, NiCo2O4 with a spinel structure was selected as a host structure with high electrical conductivity, activity, and stability to prepare Ir-doped transition metal oxides as anode catalysts for the OER. Ir-doped NCO catalysts were prepared with various concentrations of Ir as a dopant using a hydrothermal process and heat treatment. In the Ir-doped spinel structure, Ir dopants were found to occupy octahedral sites. Thus, compared with pure IrO2 and NiCo2O4, Ir-doped NCO catalysts with an optimal amount of Ir exhibited enhanced OER performance owing to the stable spinel structure of NiCo2O4, tunable electrocatalytic activity using a low amount of Ir, and the effect of IrO6 coordination geometry. In particular, the oxygen vacancies produced by Ir doping in the NCO structure could lead to enhanced OER activity owing to the increased electrical conductivity and decreased adsorption energies of OH- and H2O. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Ir-NiCo2O4 nanostructured catalysts Ir-NCO nanostructured catalysts were synthesized from NiCo2O4 using a hydrothermal process and heating with various atomic fractions of Ir from 5 to 15 at%. IrCl3 (99.9% BOYAZ Energy Co.), Co(NO3)26 H2O (98%, Sigma-Aldrich), and Ni(NO3)26 H2O (98%, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 4.0 mL of deionized (DI) water, 0.8 mL of H2O2 (35.5%, Samchun) was added and the mixture was stirred for 30 min then, 12 mL of 2.0 M NaOH (97%, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to the solution. To obtain the precursor of the Ir-NCO nanostructure catalyst, the salt solution was heated in an autoclave at 180 °C for 10 h. The resulting precursor was washed with DI water and ethanol and dried in an oven at 50 °C. The dried powder sample was heated at 400 °C in an air atmosphere for 6 h. For comparison, an Ir-free NCO nanostructured catalyst was prepared using the same procedure as the Ir-NCO samples. 2.2 Structural characterization The structural characteristics of the catalysts were analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D2 PHASER, Bruker AXS) operating at a working voltage of 30 kV with a Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm) source and a Ni filter. Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw, inVia Raman microscope) with an Ar ion laser with λ = 532 nm and a beam power of 5 mW was used to characterize the structure of the catalysts. The size distribution and crystal structure of the catalysts were analyzed using a Cs-corrected transmission electron microscope (CS-TEM, JEM ARF200F, JEOL Ltd). To characterize the shape and size of particle, field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, GeminiSE300, ZEISS) was performed under working conditions of 15 kV and 100 mA. The elemental content of the catalysts was surveyed using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer Optima 8300). The specific surface area and pore structure of the samples were characterized using an N2 adsorption/desorption analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2020, Norcross, GA). The surface chemical states were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific Inc., Al Kα u-focused monochromator: 1486.6 eV). After measuring I-V curves using a kit consisting of Teflon and stainless steel, the electrical conductivity of the powder samples was calculated as follows: (11) σ = 1 R × L A = ∆ I ∆ V × L A where σ is electrical conductivity, R is resistance, L is the length of the compressed powder sample, A is the area of the compressed powder sample, ΔI is the difference between initial and final values, and ΔV is the difference between initial and final values. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization 2.3.1 Half cell test The electrochemical properties of the catalyst samples were measured using a potentiostat (Metrohm Autolab, PGSTAT302N) in a three-electrode electrochemical cell at 25 °C. Pt wire and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were used as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. To prepare inks for electrochemical measurements, catalyst samples were mixed with DI water, isopropyl alcohol (99.7%, Sigma-Aldrich), and Nafion® ionomer solution (5 wt% Nafion, Sigma-Aldrich) by sonication and vortexing. The homogeneously mixed ink slurry was placed on a glassy carbon (GC) electrode with a diameter of 5 mm as the working electrode and then dried in an oven at 50 °C for 10 min. The resulting amount of catalyst was ~630 μg·cm−2. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out in Ar-saturated 1.0 M KOH solution in the potential range 0.1–1.3 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted in an Ar-saturated 1.0 M KOH solution at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in the potential range 1.35–1.60 V vs. RHE. The stability of the catalyst samples was tested using chronopotentiometry (CP) at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2 and a rotating speed of 3000 rpm for 20,000 s. All electrode potentials were converted to RHE using the equation E(RHE) = E(SCE) + 0.059 × pH + E0(SCE). 2.3.2 Overall water splitting test Ni foam (2 cm2, MTI Co.) was washed and sonicated with 1 M HCl, DI water, and ethanol. The washed Ni foam was dried in an oven at 50 °C. The catalyst (10 mg mL−1) was homogeneously mixed with DI water and ethanol. The Ni foam was dipped in the catalyst solution and annealed at 300 °C in an Ar atmosphere with a flow rate of 50 mL min−1. The amount of catalyst on the Ni foam was 4.3 mg cm−2. The catalyst-coated Ni foam and Pt/C on carbon paper (40 wt% of Pt, SGL Co.) were used as the anode and cathode for the overall water splitting test. The electrodes were dipped in Ar-saturated 1 M KOH at 40 °C and activated by linearly scanning in the potential range 0.9–1.6 V vs. RHE. After the activation, LSV was conducted in an Ar-saturated 1.0 M KOH solution at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in the potential range 1.0–2.0 V vs. RHE. The stability test was performed by CP at a constant current density of 50 mA cm−2 for 20 h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the catalysts The effect of H2O2 used as an oxidant in this synthesis procedure on the characteristics of the nanosized catalyst was analyzed by XRD and SEM. For the NCO sample prepared in the presence of H2O2, the XRD pattern, associated with the spinel structure of NiCo2O4 (PDF 73–1702) was observe without any other phases (Fig. S1(a)) [32]. This indicates that during the hydrothermal process, all the metal precursors were completely oxidized via the condensation reaction of the metal hydroxides [33,34]: (12) NiCo 2 OH 6 + H 2 O 2 → NiCo 2 O 4 + 4 H 2 O On the other hand, for the NCO sample prepared in the absence of H2O2, the XRD patterns, associated with Co(OH)2 (PDF 51–1731) and Ni(OH)2 (PDF 01–1047), as well as NiCo2O4 (PDF 73–1702) (Fig. S1(a)), are present. This implies that the metal precursors are only partially oxidized and be remain in the hydroxide state [35,36]. However, all the catalysts prepared from the precursors exhibited pure NiCo2O4 (PDF 73–1702) (Fig. S1(b)). The average particle sizes of the NCO samples prepared in the presence and absence of H2O2 were determined to be 27.2 and 74.7 nm, respectively (Fig. S1(d) and S1(e)). The Ir-doped NCO sample synthesized with H2O2 exhibited a single-phase crystal structure identical to that of NiCo2O4 (PDF 73–1702) and a smaller particle size (29.2 nm) than Ir-NCO synthesized without H2O2 (43.5 nm) (Fig. S2). The formation of the nanosized particles in the presence of H2O2 may be due to the prevention of sintering as a result of the condensation reaction in Eq. (12), in agreement with the H2O2 effect reported in the literature [37]. Fig. 2(a) shows the wide-range XRD patterns of the Ir-NiCo2O4 catalyst samples synthesized with various concentrations of Ir from 0 to 15 at% (0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, 15-Ir-NCO). The XRD patterns of all the samples contain XRD peaks associated with the spinel structure of NiCo2O4 (PDF 73–1702) without Ir-related phases which is the rutile structure of IrO2(PDF 15–0870). The main XRD peaks at 18.9°, 31.2°, 36.7°, 44.6°, 59.1°, and 65.0° correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes, respectively. Notably, as the concentration of Ir in the samples increased from 5 to 15 at%, the main XRD peaks corresponding to the (311) plane of the Ir-NCO samples were shifted to a lower angle, from 36.9° to 36.6° (Fig. 2(b)). This shift in XRD peak location without any other phases suggests that a solid solution is formed by adding Ir as a guest in NCO host material with a spinel structure. Based on the Hume-Rothery rule, owing to the similar crystal structure and atomic radius difference of < 15%, the Ir-NCO structure with added Ir corresponds to a substitutional solid solution [38]. According to Bragg’s law: λ = 2d·sinθ, as the distance (d) between planes increases, the diffraction angle (θ) decreases, exhibiting a shift to a lower angle in the XRD pattern [20,38]. Thus, the lower angle for the Ir-NCO samples may be attributed to the replacement by Ir with the smaller atomic radii of Ni and Co. Raman spectroscopy analysis was also performed to investigate the formation of a solid solution of the samples. In the Raman spectra of the 0-Ir-NCO and 10-Ir-NCO samples, vibration modes such as F32 g, Eg, F12 g, and A1 g corresponding to a spinel structure, appearing at ~190, ~480, ~525, and ~677 cm−1, respectively (Fig. 2(c)) [39]. In particular, as shown in Fig. 2(d), the main peaks corresponding to A1 g for 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO shifted from 676 to 666 cm−1. With increasing content of Ir in the NCO, the lower wave number for the Ir-doped sample can be attributed to the increased amount of Ir dopant [40]. In general, for pure NiCo2O4, i.e., 0-Ir NCO, the mixed valence states of nickel and cobalt may occupy tetrahedral and octahedral sites, exhibiting improved electrocatalytic activity and electrical conductivity [41]. In particular, in spinel structures such as NiCo2O4, Co2+ and Co3+ are located at tetrahedral sites and Co3+, Ni2+, and Ni3+ are located at octahedral sites [41]. Moreover, Ir3+ and Ir4+ ions can occupy some of the octahedral sites owing to the strong preference of ligands for octahedral sites [42,43]. It has also been reported that Ir atoms are located in the octahedral sites of CuIr2S4 and LiIr2O4 spinel structures [44,45]. Hence, it is expected that Ni2+, Ni3+, and Co3+ located at octahedral sites in NCO are replaced by Ir, forming Ir-doped NCO structures (Fig. 2(e)). The average particle sizes and crystal structures of the catalysts were characterized by TEM analysis ( Fig. 3). The average particle sizes of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were 19.2, 20.4, 23.5, and 51 nm, respectively. With an increasing amount of Ir dopant, the average particle size increased, which can be attributed to the effect of surface defect induced in a doped substitutional solid solution on the morphology and size [46,47]. In addition, the d-spacings of the (311) planes for 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were ~2.41, ~ 2.45 ~2.47, and ~2.5 Å, respectively. The increased d-spacing for the Ir-doped sample can attributed to a solid solution of the NCO with a spinel structure containing Ir with a relatively large atomic radius, in accordance with the XRD results. Moreover, the Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT) image of the samples were identical to those for the spinel structure of NiCo2O4. Hence, the XRD, Raman spectroscopy, and TEM data show minor amounts of Ir atoms replace Co and/or Ni atoms occupying the NiCo2O4 lattice, thereby forming a substitutional single-phase solid solution. To characterize the morphology, particle size, and elemental composition of the samples, SEM and EDS mapping images were obtained ( Fig. 4). The 0-Ir NCO with a pure NiCo2O4 structure had plate-like shapes with sharp edges, whereas the Ir-NCO samples were round in shape. The average particle sizes of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were 27.2, 26.1, 29.2, and 52.1 nm, respectively. All the samples showed a homogeneous elemental distribution of Co, Ni, and Ir, implying well-defined Ir-containing NCO structures. From the EDS and ICP analyses, the atomic ratio of Ni to Co for 0-Ir-NCO was determined to be 1:2 ( Table 1). The Ir-doped NCO samples exhibit the same atomic ratio as the undoped NCO sample, i.e., NiCo = 1:2, representing the random replacement of Ni2+, Ni3+ and Co3+ occupying octahedral sites with Ir. The measured Ir contents were also similar to the experimentally determined amounts of Ir. The specific surface areas and pore volumes of the samples were characterized by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) measurements ( Fig. 5 and Table 2). All the samples exhibited type IV isotherm N2 adsorption and desorption curves, representing the dominant presence of mesopores and micropores in the samples [48]. The BET surface areas of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were 72, 72, 61, and 49 m2 g−1, respectively. The BJH desorption cumulative pore volumes of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were 0.334, 0.179, 0.158, and 0.152 cm3 g−1, respectively. As the content of Ir in the NCO structure increased, the specific surface area and pore volume of the samples decreased. According to the literature, surface defects generated during the formation of a solid solution can affect the surface area and pore volume [46,47]. XPS analysis was performed to investigate the chemical states of the NCO samples with various amounts of Ir. The Co2p, Ni2p, Ir4f, and O1s spectra of 10-Ir-NCO are shown in Fig. 6(a)–6(d), respectively. In the Co2p spectra of 10-Ir-NCO, the main peaks of Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 for Co3+ appear at ~779.3 eV and ~794.5 eV, respectively, and the main peaks of Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 for Co2+ appear at ~781.1 and ~796.3 eV, respectively [49]. In addition, the Co2p spectra of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO contain peaks for Co3+ and Co2+ with binding energies similar to those of 10-Ir-NCO (Fig. S3). With increasing Ir content in the NCO, the ratios of Co3+/Co2+ for 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were determined to be 1.75, 1.50, 1.25, and 0.95, respectively (Fig. 6(e)). The decreased Co3+/Co2+ ratio may result from the substitution of Co3+ occupying an octahedral site with Ir4+. In the Ni2p spectra of 10-Ir-NCO, the main peaks of Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 for Ni2+ are located at ~853.6 and ~871.6 eV, respectively, and the main peaks of Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 for Ni3+ appear at ~855.4 and ~873.4 eV, respectively [49]. In addition, the Ni2p spectra of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO contain peaks of Ni3+ and Ni2+ with binding energies similar to those of 10-Ir-NCO (Fig. S4). However, with increasing Ir content in the NCO, the ratios of Ni3+/Ni2+ for the Ir-NCO samples remain constant, which can be attributed to the random replacement of Ni3+ and Ni2+ occupying octahedral sites with Ir4+. The reduction of Ni2+, Ni3+, and Co3+ was quantitatively confirmed by ICP and EDS analyses (Table 1). In general, according to the XPS profile data, the XPS Ir4f peak between 61.0 and 66.0 eV overlapped with those of Ni3p and Co3p at 60.5 and 67.3 eV, respectively (Fig. 6(c)) [21]. In the Ir4f spectrum of 10-Ir-NCO, the characteristic peaks of Ir4f7/2 and Ir4f5/2 for Ir3+ appear at ~61.9 and ~64.9 eV, respectively [24]. The Ir4f7/2 and Ir4f5/2 peaks for Ir4+ appear at ~62.6 and ~65.8 eV, respectively. In addition, the Ir4f spectra of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO contain peaks for Ir3+ and Ir4+ with binding energies similar to those of 10-Ir-NCO (Fig. S5). The O1s characteristic peaks were deconvoluted to peaks associated with metal-oxygen (M-O), oxygen vacancies, and water-adsorbed oxygen at ~529, 530, and 532 eV, respectively (Fig. 6(d)) [49]. In particular, oxygen vacancies (VO) in a doped metal oxide may be formed to compensate the electrical charge valence owing to the difference in the oxidation number between the host matrix (M3+ and M2+) and dopant (Ir4+) as follows: (13) M3+ & M2+ (NCO) → Ir4+ + 1/2 VO (Ir-NCO) The ratios of VO/M−O for 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO increased from 0.52 to 1.47. The increased VO with increasing Ir content may result from the replacement of Ir4+ with Co3+, Ni3+ and Ni2+ in the NCO structure (Fig. 6(e) and Fig. S6). The oxygen vacancies in doped oxide structures can modify the electronic density of the matrix and enhance its electrical conductivity [46]. Moreover, OH- and H2O can be easily adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies, promoting the OER activity [14,50]. The electrical conductivities of 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were 1.72 × 10−3, 2.32 × 10−2, 1.32 × 10−1, and 5.80 × 10−2 S cm−1, respectively. With increasing oxygen vacancies, the electrical conductivity increased. However, the 15-Ir-NCO containing the highest oxygen vacancies exhibited the decreased conductivity. The excessive electrons produced by the highest oxygen vacancies may hinder further increase in the conductivity [51,52]. The binding energies of the characteristic peaks associated with M−O for 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were 529.03, 529.07, 529.26, and 529.3 eV, respectively. The increased binding energy for the M−O bond with increasing Ir content may be attributed to Ir, which has a high electronegativity of 2.20 compared to those of Ni (1.91) and Co (1.88) [53]. 3.2 Electrochemical characterization of the catalysts for OER To evaluate the OER performance of the catalyst samples, LSVs were obtained at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in Ar-saturated 1.0 M KOH ( Fig. 7(a)). All the samples showed I-V curves for the OER with different slopes in the potential range between 1.4 and 1.6 V vs. RHE. The overpotential (η) for the OER in the I-V curves can be calculated using the following equation: (14) η = Emeasured − 1·23 V In Eq. (14), Emeasured is a potential value measured at 10 mA cm−2 and 1.23 V is the thermodynamic potential for the overall electrochemical reaction, i.e., water electrolysis, from Eq. (3). The η values for 0-Ir-NCO, 5-Ir-NCO, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO samples were determined to be 380, 348, 303 and 300 mV, respectively.The current density and overpotential for the OER may be dependent on the loading amount of catalyst or the type of electrode in electrochemical analysis. Specifically, the OER catalysts on porous electrodes such as Ni foam, TiO2 mesh, and carbon cloth exhibit higher current densities and lower overpotentials compared to those on a flat electrode such as glassy carbon [54–57]. Hence, in this study, to investigate the intrinsic activity of the catalysts, the OER performance on a glassy carbon electrode was evaluated in KOH electrolyte solution. Compared to state-of-the-art NCO catalysts (measured on glassy carbon electrodes in KOH solutions), despite the similar activity of 0-Ir-NCO, the 10-Ir-NCO prepared in this study exhibited an improved OER performance (Fig. S7). However, the electrocatalytic activity of 5-Ir-NCO containing 5 at% Ir for the OER was dramatically improved compared to that of 0-Ir-NCO. Furthermore, the Ir-NCO catalysts containing 10 and 15 at% Ir showed improved OER performance compared to pure IrO2 as the best OER catalyst (overpotential of ~316 mV). This demonstrates that as the amount of Ir increased, the electrochemical participation rate of Ir in the Ir-NCO samples might be significantly increased. Specifically, for the 10-Ir-NCO and 15-Ir-NCO samples, the improved electrocatalytic activity for the OER might be attributable to the presence of oxygen vacancies and IrO6 coordination geometry [58,59]. According to the literature, contraction and distortion of the Ir-O bond in Ir-containing rutile, pyrochlore, hollandite, and perovskite catalyst structures might occur because of the Jahn-Teller effect [25,26]. It has been reported that the modified Ir-O bond structure could promote the OER by facilitating the formation of OOH* , which is the rds of the OER [25,26]. In particular, the low-overpotential region in the LSV curve is linearly expressed by the Tafel slope obtained from the linear region of the Tafel plots. A relatively low slope for an OER catalyst indicates fast kinetics for the OER. The Tafel slopes for the 0-Ir NCO, 5-Ir NCO, 10-Ir NCO, and 15-Ir NCO catalyst samples were determined to be 132, 103, 78, and 83 mV dec−1, respectively, higher than that of IrO2 (59 mV dec−1) (Fig. 7(b)). Compared to 0-Ir-NCO, all the Ir-NCO catalysts showed dramatically decreased Tafel slopes, indicating enhanced OER performance owing to the addition of Ir in the NiCo2O4 structure. In particular, the Ir-NiCo2O4 samples containing 10 at% of Ir exhibited the best OER performance. The stability of the catalyst samples was tested using chronopotentiometry (CP) for 20,000 s at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2 and a rotating speed of 3000 rpm (Fig. 7(c)). After the stability test, the I-V curves for the OER were measured in the potential range 1.4–1.6 V vs. RHE (Fig. S8). The η values for 0-Ir NCO, 5-Ir NCO, 10-Ir NCO, and 15-Ir NCO were 380, 360, 317, and 312, respectively. The differences in overpotential before and after the stability test (Δη) at 10 mA·cm−2 for 0-Ir NCO, 5-Ir NCO, 10-Ir NCO, and 15-Ir NCO were 0, 12, 14, and 12 mV, respectively. Hence, the overpotentials for 0-Ir NCO, 5-Ir NCO, 10-Ir NCO, and 15-Ir NCO increased by 0%, 3.4%, 4.6%, and 4.0%, respectively (Fig. 7(d)). Compared to the same measurement for IrO2 (13%), the undoped NCO and Ir-NCO samples exhibited improved stability for the OER performance, which may be attributed to the electrocatalytic stability of the spinel structure of NiCo2O4 as a host [32]. The overall water splitting was tested in 1 M KOH at 40 °C ( Fig. 8(a)). For the overall cells, 10-Ir-NCO and IrO2 deposited on Ni foams were used as the anode catalysts and Pt/C deposited on carbon paper was used as the cathode catalyst (denoted as 10-Ir-NCO || Pt/C, 15-Ir-NCO || Pt/C and IrO2 || Pt/C, respectively). For reference, the cell with Ni foam and Pt/C as the anode and cathode catalysts (Ni || Pt/C) was tested. For the Ni || Pt/C, the overpotentials at 10, 20, and 50 mA cm−2 were 0.41, 0.49, and 0.65 V, respectively. For the IrO2 || Pt/C, the overpotentials at 10, 20, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 were 0.28, 0.33, 0.41, and 0.53 V, respectively. For the 15-Ir-NCO || Pt/C, the overpotentials at 10, 20, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 were 0.26, 0.30, 0.40, and 0.52 V, respectively. For the 10-Ir-NCO || Pt/C, the overpotentials at 10, 20, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 were 0.26, 0.30, 0.38, and 0.50 V, respectively. To evaluate the stability of the OER catalysts, the plots of potential vs time using the full cells with IrO2, 10-Ir-NCO, and 15-Ir-NCO were measured at a current density of 50 mA cm−2 for 20 h (Fig. 8(b)). Compared to pure IrO2, the 10-Ir-NCO and 15-Ir-NCO with a doped spinel structure exhibited the improved stable OER performance. In particular, in comparison with the 15-Ir-NCO, the enhanced stability of the 10-Ir-NCO might be attributed to the relatively high specific surface area and improved electrical conductivity. In addition, the durability test for overall water splitting with the 10-Ir-NCO as the best catalyst was performed at a current density of 50 mA cm−2 for 200 h. The 10-Ir-NCO || Pt/C maintained the OER activity for 200 h (Fig. S9). In particular, the XPS analysis of the 10-Ir-NCO after the stability test was performed (Fig. S10) [60]. The Ir4f spectrum of the 10-Ir-NCO after the stability test were similar to the pristine before the test. In the O1s spectrum, the portion of the peak associated with water adsorbed oxygen and oxygen vacancy was slightly increased, resulting from the adsorption of OH- and H2O during the OER, however, exhibiting no serious effect on the activity [61–63]. Consequently, the 10-Ir-NCO anode catalyst with an optimal amount of Ir dopant exhibited the improved OER activity and stability in overall water splitting tests, as compared with the state-of-the-art OER catalysts on porous electrodes ( Table 3) [64–76]. 4 Conclusions In summary, we synthesized mesoporous Ir-doped NCO catalysts to improve their OER performance. The Ir-doped NCO catalysts for the OER exhibited a spinel structure with a complete substitutional solid solution. In particular, the oxygen vacancies produced by Ir doping could improve electrical conductivity and promote the adsorption of OH- and H2O. Moreover, the IrO6 coordination geometry, formed by the replacement of Ni and Co located in octahedral sites with Ir, could lead to enhanced electrocatalytic activity for the OER, compared to IrO2 as a representative OER catalyst. Consequently, an Ir-doped NCO catalyst with an optimized atomic amount of Ir in the NiCo2O4 structure exhibited enhanced activity and stability for the OER. coredata.dc:description: Water electrolysis (WE) is an attractive advanced technology for the production of H2. A key issue in the WE is to develop suitable catalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), where a relatively large energy loss occurs. The Ir-doped NiCo2O4 catalysts exhibit the formation of a solid solution and a porous nanostructure. The oxygen vacancies formed by Ir doping can enhance the electrocatalytic activity for the OER owing to increased electrical conductivity and tunable adsorption energies of OH- and H2O. In comparison to IrO2 as a representative OER catalyst, the Ir(10 at%) doped NiCo2O4 catalyst (10-Ir-NCO) exhibits the better OER performance (overpotential of 303 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and its stability for 20,000 s. In addition, in the overall water splitting test, the 10-Ir-NCO || Pt/C exhibits the excellent OER activity (a low overpotential of 0.5 V at 100 mA cm−2) and stability (20 h at 50 mA cm−2).
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous Spinel Ir-doped NiCo2O4 Nanostructure as an Efficient Catalyst for Oxygen Evolution Reaction
